While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients can run successful businesses. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Odongerel

texts.en: Odongerel B. is 41 years old single mother who lives with her two children in the Baganuur, one of the remote district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. She and her two children live together in an apartment. Her son, Tsolmongerel, is a studies at the Mongolian Science and Technology University while her daughter, Hulan, attends a local high school. Odongerel lets her own garage to others as a renting space where individuals rent and operate a car washing center and wheel repairing center. She has been providing rent service to others for past 6 years and has built s stable and successful operation. In the future, she plans to provide a service of lubricated oil replacement and to sell an accumulator. Her main goal is to provide for her children's education and to help them become a good and responsible person. For the future, she hopes to start her auto repair related business, and is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to increase her working capital by 2,000,000 MNT and to pay her son's accomodation fees at 1,000,000 MNT.

loans.use: To increase working capital and to pay her son's university fees

loans.name: Young Generation Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Young Generation” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to invest in their businesses. 

Mamusu B. is the leader of this group. Mamusu is thirty-six years old, married with two children who are attending primary school. Mamusu sells shoes, socks, and vests. With the help of this loan, Mamusu will invest in her business by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy shoes, socks, vests, etc. wholesale for resale

loans.name: Estela

texts.en: Estela B. is a hardworking mother. As a typical Filipino mother she used to stay in the house doing the usual household chores. But now that her children are grown, she wants to mingle with other people, develop her personality, take away her shyness and improve her income as well. She joined Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), a partner of Kiva in the Philippines, to fund her variety store and to join the group of ASHI members in her community. On her second loan, she is applying for PHP 9500. With the loan, she will buy grocery products so that she can meet the demands of her growing customer base and increase her profit. She is saving all her income from this variety store so that she can buy a motorcycle, which she needs to transport her products. She is hoping that Kiva lenders will support her in achieving her dreams for her family and continue to assist her financially until she becomes a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her variety store

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: The poverty and discrimination Lorna M. has witnessed and experienced inspired her to join Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), in 2005, determined to improve her standard of living. Today, Lorna is a respected and very active member of ASHI, a partner of Kiva in the Philippines. She is applying for a loan of PHP 8500 to finance her meat business. She will use her loan money to buy frozen meat foods and sell them to the community. Her future business plan is to buy a freezer so that she can stock more products. Moreover, she has gained knowledge about the preparation of processed meat products and hopes some day to do the processing herself. She is praying that ASHI and Kiva will keep on supporting her until she reaches her goal.

loans.use: To buy processed meat products for resale

loans.name: Sheridan

texts.en: Sheridan E. is a 38-year-old mother of three children. The eldest, 16, is a college student and the two youngest, 9 and 11, are elementary grade pupils. The family’s main source of income is the salary of her husband, but the cost of living in the city is so expensive that she decided to help her husband with their financial needs. She looked for people to help her financially and she found Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a partner of Kiva in the Philippines. She was encouraged to join because of the principles and program that the institution offers. She consulted her husband about her plan, he approved, and she became a member in 2004. She used her previous loans to start a small store business. Her husband is grateful because his wife now helps to support the family. Sheridan is happy as well because, as years passed, her customers have increased and she is earning more. Now she is applying for another loan of PHP 23000 to buy more grocery products. She wants to buy more sacks of rice for retail, soft drinks, liquors, canned goods, assorted snack foods and noodles, kitchen ingredients and personal beauty products. She will be delighted if Kiva lenders will assist her financially. She is hoping that the partnership of ASHI and Kiva will continue and prosper.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery products for her store

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia R., 69, is married with three children, ages 49, 47 and 43. Her business is weaving doormats that are made up of scrap textile bought in kilos from a nearby garment factory. She has workers who weave her doormats. She sells them in bulk to buyers who go to her place, or she delivers them directly to market stalls. She is happy with her income because it not only helps her family but it also gives employment to families in her neighborhood. She is a very dedicated and active member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a partner of Kiva in the Philippines. She is applying for a new loan of PHP 12000 to purchase materials for her business. She hopes that ASHI and Kiva will continue to help her in her goal of not just providing financial support for her children and their family but also creating employment in their community.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for doormat weaving

loans.name: Amartuvshin

texts.en:
Amartuvshin N. lives with his wife and children in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Amartuvshin supports his family by operating a successful taxi service in his town, an enterprise he started in 2007 after moving to his current province. For the future, he and his wife are planning to start a grocery business by renting small space where they will sell a variety of foodstuffs. His hope is to soon expand the business.

A very modest and polite man, Amartuvshin is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase groceries such as bread, pastries, flour, rice and candies from wholesale stores in the capital city of the province for his future grocery shop.

loans.use: To purchase groceries such as bread, pasties, flour, and rice for a new business

loans.name: Sapakamapie Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Sapakamapie” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka town.  They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further improve on the size and quality of their respective businesses.

Pictured on the left is Salaymatu B. who is the leader of this group. Salaymatu was born in northern Sierra Leone; she is thirty-five. She is married to a seaman and the couple has six children – one in primary school, four in secondary school, and the other is not attending school.

Salaymatu who has been a businesswoman for twenty years now sells fried cakes. With this loan, she will buy bags of rice and flour to produce more cakes to sell.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and flour to produce more cakes to sell

loans.name: Ibrogim

texts.en:
Ibrogim, who is married and has four children, lives in Isfara, Northern Tajikistan, where he offers technical maintenance services in his home. Ibrogim decided to launch this business 15 years ago because he has always loved working with technical systems. He is now seeking a loan of 7500 Somoni to purchase necessary materials and spare parts. He believes his business policy, which allows for deferred payments, will be an attraction for his customers and will help him stand out among his competitors. Ibrogim has repaid his previous two loans from IMON International, both of which contributed to the growth of his business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase spare parts and a diagnostic device for repair of electronic equipment

loans.name: Bazarragchaa

texts.en: Bazarragchaa B. is a 43-year-old single parent who lives with her daughter and her sibling in the province of Uvs in Mongolia. She and her daughter live in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter, age 14, attends local secondary school. Bazarragchaa started her own business in 2000 by exporting a variety of clothes in the city of Tuba in Russia. Currently she works as a translator with Russian small and medium entrepreneurs. During the spring and autumn, she sells sea-buckthorn seedlings, imported from Russia, in the province of Selenge. Her current working capital exceeds 5,000,000 MNT, and she is planning to plant sea-buckthorn in her own two-hectare field in the future. Her dream is to provide higher education for her only daughter so that she will be able to live a decent life. Bazarragchaa is a very open-minded and talkative woman, and she is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more sea-buckthorn seedlings to sell for profit.

loans.use: To purchase more seedlings of sea-buckthorn

loans.name: Bobokhon

texts.en:
B. Bobokhon is a young man who has been a farmer for 15 years. He is happily married to a hardworking woman who always supports him. She has helped him get ahead in life and has given him four children. Like most other people in the zone who depend on the vegetable crop, Bobokhon needs to buy agricultural supplies that will allow for the maintenance and production of crops up to the optimum harvest time. With this purpose in mind, Bobokhon applied for a loan of 5,000 somoni from IMON International to purchase agricultural supplies like seeds and fertilizer. Bobokhon and his beloved family sincerely thank you for your support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON’s History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Peter Were

texts.en:
Peter Were E. is 31 years old and married to Mildred Atieno. Together they have one child who is two years old. He operates a barber shop as his primary business and a salon as a secondary. His business is situated in Huruma, near Redeemed Gospel Church, and most of his clients are youths and young boys. He gets an income of 7,000 KES per month and has been in this business for two years.

He came to learn about KADET LTD through an existing customer of KADET, and he does not have any history with any other MFI. Peter is applying for his first loan of 10,000 KES, with which he intends to purchase more blow-dryers and a chair. He plans to plough back the income he gets with an aim to grow the business.

In the future, he plans to own a beauty and fashion school so that he can nurture the talents of youths who are jobless in the community. He believes that this step will improve his business and provide a stable flow of income.

loans.use: To purchase more blow-dryers and a chair.

loans.name: Norjmoo

texts.en: Norjmoo A. is a 49 year-old widow who lives with her three children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Her youngest son attends a local secondary school. Norjmoo operates a variety of businesses in order to provide for her family. She has been operating a water hole since 2007. Her customers are usually neighboring households. During the summer, her oldest daughter runs the water hole while Norjmoo operates a construction business with help of her children. During the winter months, they go through the countryside selling a variety of products to supplement the family's income. Norjmoo hopes to built a stable and successful operation that can improve their family's standard of living. She is requesting a 300,000 MNT loan to purchase stationary and clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase stationary and clothes to sell

loans.name: United Sisters I Group

texts.en:
Adama J. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born twenty-eight years ago in Magburaka town, Adama is single and has one daughter who is attending primary school. Adama is a hairdresser; she has been running a salon for many years now. She also sells soft drinks and cold water in her salon. Adama will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business; she will buy hair extensions wholesale to sell in her salon. 

This is the second loan that Adama and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of their previous Kiva loan, they were able to increase the size and quality of their respective businesses.

loans.use: Buy hair extensions wholesale to sell in her salon

loans.name: Kulmira

texts.en:
Kulmira A. is a 43 year-old widow with four children. She finished secondary school at the age of 20 and got married. Kulmira’s husband worked at the local factory as a driver but his wage was too low to meet the needs of his growing family. To find an additional means of income, Kulmira and her husband started to sell vegetables at the market. This brought in a regular profit, which afterwards became the basis for a livestock-breeding business in which, with much effort, Kulmira achieved success. The level of the family's existence began to gradually improve, but in 2005 Kulmira’s husband died suddenly and she became the only bread-winner. She had a hard time, but didn’t give in doing everything she could to stabilize her children’s life. Today Kulmira has two cows and one horse at her farm. Also, with the help of her youngest son, Kulmira has broadened her business by selling meat products at the market. Kulmira wants a loan of 50,000 KGS to buy bull-calves to fatten and resell. With the revenue from this investment, Kulmira plans to buy a house for her son, who is now serving in the army. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the most vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading micro-finance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that leads to increased employment and meets the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Ganmyagmar

texts.en: Mrs.Ganmyagmar is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her eldest daughter sews in a clothing factory and her son is in secondary school. She has two more children who are grown and live separately. Her husband works as a butcher in the local food market. Between 2005 and 2009, Mrs. Ganmyagmar used to rent a small space inside the local grocery shop to sell a variety of products. But the owner of the shop sold it so she had to change her business location and profile accordingly. At the moment she rents a stall inside the market in one of the busiest and most crowded areas of the city, selling clothes. She said that her new business has more competitors, but is still giving a better return then the older one. Since 2005, when she started her retail business, she has bought a minivan for her family and also obtained a license to own a piece of land. Her future plan is to build a house on her land. The loan she is requesting will be used to increase her working capital and inventory in her business.

loans.use: to increase her working capital and inventory

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta C. is 43 years old and a determined mother of three children — a 19 year-old college student, and two high-school students. She is a native of the island village located in the heart of Laguna de Bay Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Elmer who is 49 years old. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2008 because she needed capital to restore her ready-to-wear clothes business. When she received her loan, she carefully invested the money in her business and now has regular customers and increased income.

Julieta is requesting a fourth loan of Php 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her RTW business and variety store. She will buy shoes, clothes, and slippers, and grocery products, plus a sack of concentrate and hog feed. She is optimistic that her business will continue to grow now that she has the support of ASHI and the trust of KIVA lenders. She dreams of making her business grow, and wants to invest more in it.

loans.use: to buy ready-to-wear clothes, shoes, slippers plus sacks of hog feeds

loans.name: Igor

texts.en:
Igor is married with two grown children. He is a businessman from Uzhgorod selling used clothing. He owns two kiosks at one of the local markets called ‘RIO’ and has a loyal clientele. His merchandise is always varied and in demand. He makes about 5,000 Grivnyas net profit a month.    

Igor has been running his used-clothing sales business for 12 years  He is requesting a loan of 8,000 Grivnyas to increase his turnover capital. He has gained an impeccable reputation among his fellow market vendors as a financially reliable and prudent entrepreneur, and plans to continue expanding his trade and improving his living standard in the process.

loans.use: to increase his capital

loans.name: Tuleujan

texts.en:
Tuleujan A. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent, in Bayan-Ulgiy Province in western Mongolia. His wife is currently unemployed and stays home watching their youngest daughter, while the other two children attend a local primary school.

In his town, Tuleujan currently operates a transportation business which he began in 1995 by transporting and delivering a variety of loads using his own truck. During the summer months, he uses his small car as a taxi, transporting people between two sub provinces, while in winter months he transports and sells firewood and coal in the local market. As well, Tuleujan transports loads between Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city and Tashkent, a city in China. Over the years, he has built a stable and successful operation and gained much experience as a driver. His truck can carry up to 13 tons of coal at one time, earning him a net profit of between 5000 and 1000 MNT per ton of coal. His profits have enabled him to build a new house with three rooms.

A very honest and hardworking man, Tuleujan says, "I want to save money for my children's future education." He is now requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to repair the small car he uses as a taxi and to purchase more coal from the countryside and four new wheels for his vehicle.

loans.use: To purchase more coal

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena, who is divorced with two children, sells clothing at one of the markets in Berdyansk city, earning a monthly net income of 3,000 Grivnas. This enterprise is her only source of income. In this business for 10 years now, good pricing policy, good client service, and a strong desire to go forward have helped Olena make her business a success.

Olena would like to borrow 10,000 Grivnas to increase the assortment she has to sell. The additional income will be spent on her family's needs: food, medicine, some clothing, etc.

loans.use: To increase her assortment of clothing for sale

loans.name: No Joke Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “No Joke” group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the northern township of Magburaka. They are requesting a loan of SLL 800,000 for each in the group.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. 

Aminata K. K. is the leader of this group. Aminata was born in Matotoka village, about eight miles from Magburaka town. She is thirty-five years old, married to a driver, and they have three children – one in primary school and two in secondary school.  Aminata will use her share of the loan to buy palm oil, rice and groundnuts to add to her business inventory. Aminata has been selling the above-mentioned items for ten years now.

loans.use: Buy palm oil, rice and groundnuts for resale

loans.name: Tarzan

texts.ru:
Tarzan G. 51 qod. On jenat i imeyet 3 detey, doch kotoroy 20 let ona uchitsya v universitete , sin kotoromu 18 let on v etom qodu postupil v universitet i doch 16 let kotoraya yesho uchitsya v shkole. Tarzan yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda, i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli region vmeste so svoyey semyoy.

Tarzan uje 10 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom skotovodstva. Seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi.
texts.en:
Tarzan G. is 51 years old. He is married and has three children: a 20-year daughter who is a university student; an 18-year old son who was just admitted to the university this year; and a 16-year old daughter who is still in school. Tarzan is an Internally Displaced Person. He is a refugee from the town of Fuzuli, now living with his family in the Fuzuli Region.

He has been in the cattle raising business for 10 years. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy a cow.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To perform maintenance on his printings machines

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of slippers

loans.name: Tawopaneh Group

texts.en:
Fatmata B.  (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of two entrepreneurs. Born thirty-six years ago in Magburaka town, Fatmata is married and has five children.  For ten years now, Fatmata has been selling fish, salt, Maggi cubes, palm oil, etc. Fatmata will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business; she will buy fish, salt, Maggi, palm oil, etc. 

This is the first loan that Fatmata and her group member have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: Buys fish, salt, Maggi cubes, palm oil, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 27-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his family. He has owned a perfume and pocketbook shop in his town since 2003. His shop is well known because he always tries to offer the new brands to his local customers.  In almost all parts of Lebanon, demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high.  His brother is out of Lebanon so he is the one who is helping his father with the household expenses. He is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase his inventory selection. In the future, he wishes to continue expansion of his shop and he hopes that he will be able to open a new branch some day.

loans.use: To increase his inventory selection

loans.name: Honest-Ii Group

texts.en:
Fatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fatu was born in Magburaka town about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple has four children, two in primary school and two in secondary school.

For a long period of time now, Fatu has been selling cooked rice (the country’s staple food). This is the first loan that Fatu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Fatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business; she will buy cooking ingredients like rice, palm oil (the locally favorite cooking oil), etc. in large quantity. In this way, Fatu will stop buying retail, thereby saving her a lot of money.

loans.use: Buy cooking ingredients like rice, palm oil, etc. in large quantity

loans.name: Yousef

texts.en:
Yousef is a hard working man from Tulkarem, married and a father of three daughters. Yousef is a plumber and makes a good living out of his work. Yousef has taken an $850 loan to cover expenses related to his house and caring for his three daughters. Yousef prefers to cover these expenses with a loan from FATEN because it is easier for him to repay on monthly basis than all at once.

Yousef's brother is a previous borrower of FATEN, and the family are known of their commitment and hard work. Yousef appears in the picture above in FATEN's office.

loans.use: Pay off debt

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 33-year-old married man and the father of 3 school-aged children. He is an experienced furniture carpenter; he has owned a carpentry shop for almost fifteen years. He is his family's main income provider. Today, he wants to borrow $1000 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.; he will use the money to purchase an air compressor. This will be his second loan and he is very thankful for the results. In the future, he is looking to further expand his merchandise and invest in a new wood-sanding machine. He hopes that the coming year will continue to bring positive growth and increased sales.

loans.use: purchasing an air compressor

loans.name: María Luisa

texts.es:
La Sra. María Luisa M. Valdivia es comerciante activa su actividad económica  es venta de tortilla, posol,  tiste y nacatamales su negocio está ubicado en el Reparto primero de mayo con 21 años de experiencia en el negocio.

Este crédito lo utilizo para comprar al por mayor el producto para la elaboración de tortillas para así obtener mayores ingresos, y  lograr a mantener  su hogar ya que es madre  soltera con un hijo a su cargo.  

La Sra. M. Valdivia le agradece a ceprodel porque le ha ayudado que su negocio crezca y así a logrado a mejorar su vivienda.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Luisa M. Valdivia is a merchant.  She sells tortillas, posol (corn flour-based drink), tiste (corn and cacao-based drink) and nacatamales (Nicaraguan tamales popular as weekend fare).   Her business is located in Reparto Primero de Mayo and she has 21 years experience in this line of work.

She used the loan to buy ingredients to make tortillas at wholesale so that she could obtain higher income and support her household since she’s a single mother with a son in her care.

Mrs. M. Valdivia thanks Ceprodel because it has helped her business grow and she has thus been able to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To buy corn, firewood and lime powder.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and six siblings. In 2008, she opened a mini supermarket in her town. She helps her father, who works as a farmer, and her brothers in the household. Today, she wants to borrow $1000 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. in order to increase her store’s inventory. She expects that her business will continue to grow in the coming year. 

In Lebanon, small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods are found frequently. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: increasing her store's inventory

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La Sra. Luz Marina G. Ruiz,  es comerciante activa su actividad económica  es venta de ropa usada, su negocio está ubicado en el Reparto primero de mayo con 4 años de experiencia en el negocio.

Este crédito lo utilizo para comprar pacas de mejor calidad el cual le agradece a ceprodel porque hoy compra su producto por pacas ya que antes de obtener créditos compraba por pieza el producto.
texts.en:
Sra. Luz Marina G. Ruiz is an active merchant who sells used clothing in order to earn a living. Her business is located in the May 1st District and she has four years of experience in this field.

This loan will be used to buy bundles of high quality clothing. She is grateful to CEPRODEL because she can now buy merchandise in bundles. Prior to this, she had to buy individual garments on credit.

loans.use: Purchase two bundles of high quality clothing

loans.name: United Family Group

texts.en:
Saah M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called United Family.  He is 26 years old and married with four children who are between the ages of 20 months and 9 years. He was only able to attend school through 5th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For five years, he has been selling door locks, hinges, nails, zinc, hammers, etc., in Clara Town in Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 12,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 44,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more door locks, hinges, nails, zinc, hammers, etc. He describes himself as a quiet man whose dream is to improve his business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Alex is inset in the photo in the lower right corner because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more door locks, hinges, nails, zinc, hammers, etc.

loans.name: Martha Águeda

texts.es:
La Sra. Martha Águeda E. T.,  es comerciante activa su actividad económica  es venta refrescos, su negocio está ubicado en el mercado central, con 10 años de experiencia en el negocio, además su esposo vende ambulante.

Este crédito lo utilizo para comprar Azúcar, cacao, semilla, payana, canela, leche y frutas, el cual le agradece a ceprodel ya que con los prestamos ha logrado construir su local de trabajo y de realizar las compras de productos al por mayor.
texts.en:
Sra. Martha Águeda E. T. is an active merchant who sells soft drinks to earn a living. Her business is located at the central market. She has ten years of experience managing her business. In addition, her husband works as a street vendor.

This loan will be used to buy sugar, cocoa, seeds, sticky rice, cinnamon, milk, and fruit. She is grateful to CEPRODEL because the loans that have been provided have enabled her to build a shop from which she can work and purchase goods in bulk.

loans.use: Purchase sugar, cocoa, seeds, sticky rice, cinnamon, milk, and fruit

loans.name: Good Family Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesspeople in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 600,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 600,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feeding and clothing them. 

Ibrahim C. (left) is the leader of this group. He was born in Magburaka town thirty-seven years ago. He is married and has four children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending schools – three in primary school and one in secondary school. 

Ibrahim sells palm oil, pepper, rice, etc. He has been a businessman for many years now. With his share of the loan, he will expand his business by buying the above-mentioned items in bulk to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy palm oil, pepper, rice, etc. in large quantity

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “United Sisters” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 400,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Adama S.. Adama is age thirty; she was born in Magburaka. She is married with three children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools.  

For many years now, Adama has been selling market food – pepper, salt, palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), etc. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: Buy pepper, salt, palm oil, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Aura Magaly

texts.es:
La Sra. Aura Magaly Q. G.  es comerciante activa del mercado central, tiene 39 años, es madre soltera de dos hijas, se dedica a la venta de ropa con experiencia de 23 años en el negocio.

Este crédito lo utilizo para Compra de pañales, calcetines, toallas, blúmer, etc., se siente muy contenta con los créditos que se ceprodel le ha otorgado ya que ha logrado incrementar su capital de trabajo y así ha podido mejorar su nivel de vida tanto el de ella como el de sus hijas.
texts.en:
Sra. Aura Magaly Q. G. is an active merchant at the central market. She is 39 years old and a single mother of two daughters. Aura sells clothing and has 23 years of experience in this business.

This loan will be used to buy diapers, socks, towels, undergarments, and other products. She is very pleased with the loans CEPRODEL has provided because they have allowed her to increase her operating capital and improve the quality of life for herself and her daughters.

loans.use: Purchase diapers, socks, towels, undergarments, and other products

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal, palm oil and salt

loans.name: Aida Patricia

texts.es: Aida Patricia tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación, por lo que se siente muy agradecida por los financiamientos.  Ella tiene 2 hijos menores de edad a su cargo, su actividad económica es la venta de leña, se dedica hace más de 7 años a este negocio, por lo que siempre está pensando en proporcionarles a sus hijos lo más necesario. Por lo que es muy reconocida por sus vecinos, amigos y familiares que llegan a comprar. Este crédito es para la compra de leña. Ella sueña con mantener activo su negocio, ya que es su medio de vida.
texts.en: Aida Patricia has worked with Fundación for a long time and is very grateful for the loans she has received. She has two young children to take care of. She has been in the business of selling firewood for over 7 years and is always focusing on providing her children with everything they need. Her neighbours, friends and relatives all know she is trustworthy and buy from her. This loan is to buy firewood. She wants to keep her business moving, as it is how she earns her living.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Wega Group

texts.en:
Anjelina M., who is in her mid-forties, is married with three children.  She has a powered soap, sarong and fabrics business. She started her business 2 years ago and works daily from 10am until 6pm. She is able to earn a good monthly profit. 

This will be  Anjelina’s  1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan to buy more stock of all her products. 
	
Anjelina will share this loan with her loan group, Wega, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

 In the picture, Anjelina is 2nd from left, front row.

loans.use: To increase  her stock of all her products

loans.name: Isabel Antonio

texts.pt:
Isabel Antônio M. nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, solteira e ainda não tem filhos. Não estudou porque os pais na altura priorizaram as atividades agrícolas e pastagem de gado bovino para garantirem o sustento da família. Vive na casa própria e sustenta seu sobrinho de 3 anos de idade que vive com ele. 

Saiu de Gaza para Maputo com os seus pais quando estes vinham atrás de um emprego. Trabalha numa empresa de produção e venda de banana ha mais de 5 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e tem um salario de 1.770.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum de vez enquanto na sua conta bancaria.
 
Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas que já se beneficiaram de serviços desta instituição. Este é o primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, barrotes, pedra, areia, chapas de zinco e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência.

Esta confiante que vai pagar sem nenhum problema e pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir e mobilar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Isabel Antônio M. was born in the District of Manjacaze, Province of Gaza in the south of Mozambique.  She is single and has no children.  She didn't attend school because at that point her parents made agricultural activities and raising cattle a priority to ensure the maintenance of the family.  She lives in her own house and supports her three-year-old nephew, who lives with her.

She left Gaza for Maputo with her parents when they came for employment.  She has worked in a factory and sold bananas for over five years.  She has no employees, and has a salary of 1,770 MT per month, which she uses for household expenses and still sets some aside now and then in her bank account.

She has never had a loan from another bank and got to know about Hluvuku through colleagues who already benefit from the services of this institution.  This is her first loan — at a value of 10,000 MT — with which she intends to purchase construction materials (cement, beams, stone, sand, corrugated metal, and other items) in order continue with the construction of her house.

She is confident that she will repay without any problem and will ask for a new loan to finish construction and furnish her home.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials (cement, beams, stone, sand, corrugated metal, and other items)

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 38 years old and a member of the Jiinuwe Ngando group. He runs Emirates Pool Table House, where he offers recreational activities such as playing pool and table games. He has very friendly customers.  He has been running the business for five years.  

Joseph is a hardworking and business-oriented man who also rents out houses to earn extra income. He is currently running his business with three employees and he hopes to succeed in his business and employ more people.  

He has requested a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a new pool table and renovate his rental houses.

loans.use: To buy a new pool table and renovate rental houses

loans.name: Sisters Of Bong Mines Bridge Group

texts.en:
Gorpu T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called 'Sisters Of Bong Mines Bridge'.  She is 43 years old, single, and has three children between the ages of 14 and 21 years. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to financial difficulties.

For 14 years, she has been selling palm oil and rice in Bong Mines Bridge Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 21,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice and gallons of palm oil. She describes herself as a very hard-working woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sweetie is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Jerónima Lilian

texts.es:
La Sra. Jerónima Lilian B. M., es comerciante activa de la plaza mercado central, tiene 45 años, es madre soltera de tres hijas, se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general con experiencia de 15 años en el negocio.

Este crédito lo utilizo para Compra de cerámica, shampoo, cremas corporales, vanidades, pinturas, vestidos, almohadas, etc., la Sra. inicia primer crédito con ceprodel para poder aumentar su capital de trabajo y mejor la calidad de vida de ella y de sus hijas.
texts.en:
Sra. Jerónima Lilian B. M. is an active merchant at the central plaza market. She is 45 years old and a single mother of three daughters. Jerónima sells general merchandise and has 15 years of experience.

This loan will be used to buy ceramics, shampoo, body crèmes, fashion magazines, polishes, dresses, pillows, and other products. Sra. Jerónima used her first loan from CEPRODEL to increase her operating capital and improve the quality of life for her daughters.

loans.use: Purchase ceramics, shampoo, body crèmes, fashion magazines, polishes, dresses, pillows, and other products

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac is a 30-year-old married man with one child.  He has been operating a cafeteria for six years.  In his cafeteria, he mainly sells chicken.  He is also a farmer who grows maize to earn a living.  He hopes to become a self-reliant businessman in the future.  He wants to expand his business and start rearing his own chickens for sale.  He has been able to improve his business with the support of Faulu Kenya.  

Isaac has requested 80,000 Kes to buy chickens, sodas, and a freezer.  He says that he is a hardworking man who is aiming to get to higher levels in his business.

loans.use: To buy chickens, sodas, and a freezer

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man and the father of 5 school-aged children. He is an experienced construction worker. He is especially talented at completing woodwork and gypsum board projects. He has been doing this for the past 12 years. He works with some entrepreneurs and constructs things for the clients. Today, he wants to borrow $1200 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. in order to purchase the construction supplies needed for his newest project.

loans.use: purchasing construction supplies

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 28 years old and married.  He owns a cafeteria which he has been running for six years.  He is a member of Upendo women's group in Faulu Kenya.  He says that he has learnt how to keep track of his business profits through Faulu Kenya.  

Currently, he runs the business with two employees and he hopes to develop his business further.  He sees himself owning several cafeterias in the future.  He has requested 70,000 Kes to buy rice, maize flour, beans, Irish potatoes, cooking fat, tea leaves and milk.

loans.use: To buy rice, maize flour, beans, Irish potatoes, cooking fat, tea leaves and milk

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is 26 years old, married, and blessed with a six-year-old child who is in school.  He runs David Enterprise business where he sells bananas.  He has been running the business for three years and has managed to employ two people.  He says that his business has many customers.  Since he became a member of Faulu Kenya, he has become self-reliant.  He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kes to buy green bananas.  He wants to buy a truck for transport in the future.

loans.use: To buy green bananas

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Saada

texts.en: Saada  is a married lady with four children.  For the past ten years, she has been selling fabric.  Her business is located in Kibera slum in Nairobi (capital city of Kenya).  Therefore, most of her customers are low income earners.  Besides fabric, she sells tea leaves.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping her to set up her current business and she is now getting big orders.  She dreams of importing fabric from the Asian market in the future. She has requested 60,000 Kes to buy fabric and leso (Africa design fabric).

loans.use: To buy fabric and leso (Africa design fabric)

loans.name: Salvador De Jesus

texts.es: Salvador De Jesús es un hombre de 57 años, la necesidad lo ha impulsado a obtener su propio negocio de de venta de mercadería en general. Este es su primer Financiamiento con Fundación planea comprar una amplia variedad de productos como pantalones, cosméticos, calzado y oro está necesitando de este capital de trabajo adicional para responderles a sus clientes que le solicitan variedad. El buen carisma que ofrece es lo que hace que obtenga más clientes y un mercado mejor segmentado. Su sueño es llegar a tener una tienda, en donde pueda ofertar diferentes productos a sus clientes.
texts.en: Salvador de Jesus is a 57 year old man. The need for work empowered him to set up his own business, selling general merchandise. This is his first loan from Fundacion (Kiva Field Partner) and he plans on purchasing a wide variety of products such as pants, cosmetics, shoes, and gold. He requires working capital to be able to fill his clients' demand for variety.  He is able to win new clients with his wonderful charisma, reaching various sectors of the market. His dream is to have a store where he will be able to sell various products to his clients.

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita M. is a 50-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  Vegetable vending and Pig-fattening businesses. She lives in Purok Ceresa, Brgy. Bayabas, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her   vegetable vending and pig-fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4500. Nenita is now borrowing PHP 18,000 so that she can  buy fertilizers and vegetables.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Nenita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.

 About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: God Alive Group

texts.en:
Oretha M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called 'God Alive'.  She is 27 years old, married, and has one child who is three years old. She was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of financial support. She cares for four siblings.

For 11 years, she has been operating a bakery in Duala Market in Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of flour, sugar, butter, oil, baking powder, yeast, etc. She describes herself as a very quiet woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Helena is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of flour, sugar, butter, oil, baking powder, yeast, etc.

loans.name: Velenda

texts.en:
Velenda E. is a married woman who lives in Purok Tuway, Brgy. Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  General Store and Food Vending businesses. Her husband Roberto E., who is 34 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are 3 to 8 years old. 

Velenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 8 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Velenda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 9th loan, she is borrowing PHP 23,000 which she intends to use to buy more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and for home repairs. 

Velenda E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for her general store

loans.name: Salina Cheokemboi

texts.en:
Salina Cheokemboi N. is 42-year-old lady married to John N. Muiru who is a farmer. They have two children aged 25 and 12. They live in Kapsoya, an outlying area of Edoret town.

Salina is a tailor; she has run her business for the past eight years and the business is doing well. She is applying for her sixth loan with KADET LTD  to enable her to buy a sewing machine. She was introduced to KADET LTD  by a friend who is a client. 

She hopes to have an established tailoring shop in the area to capture the large market demand. She also hopes to build a permanent house and also to see her children get the best education.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn M. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Kalubihan, Brgy. San Antonio, Himamaylan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  General Store and Cane Planter (Arendo) businesses. Her husband Eriberto Miguil Jr., who is 33 years old, works as a Tricycle (three-wheeled transport vehicle) Driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 3 and  9 years old. 

Ailyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ailyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 24,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 12th loan, she is borrowing PHP 26,000, which she intends to use to pay for inventory for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Ailyn M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Think Big Group

texts.en:
Stephen K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Think Big.  He is 32 years old, single, and has one child who is four years old. He is a junior student at a local university.

For 10 years, he has been selling bags, used towels and t-shirts in Duala Market in Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 25,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 100,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more cartons of bags, used towels and t-shirts. He describes himself as a hard-working man whose dream is to improve his business and  build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Annie is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of bags, used towels and t-shirts

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita N. is a married woman who lives in Purok Tuway, Brgy. Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  Fishing and Fish Selling businesses. Her husband Dominador N. Jr., who is 49 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 6 children who are 18 to  35 years old. 

Lolita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1996 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lolita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to pay for more maintenance on their fishing boat  so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of the business. 

Lolita N. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: maintenance for fishing boat

loans.name: Samuel Kiprugut

texts.en:
Samuel Kiprugut K., a 50-year-old gentleman married to Leah K., is the father of three children aged 26, 22 and 18 years. The sole bread winner in the family, as his wife does not work, Samuel been a shopkeeper for the past six years, earning a profit of about Kshs 10,000 every month.

A client of KADET LTD, he is now requesting his seventh loan, having repaid his previous loans on time. He is planning to use the amount to buy five boxes of cooking oil and five bundles of maize flour, and hopes to make a profit which he will use to boost his business. Samuel has plans of opening other branches in the future so that he can improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy five boxes of cooking oil and five bundles of maize flour.

loans.name: Everlyne Masitsa

texts.en:
Everlyne Masitsa L. is a 36-year-old lady who is married to Cronelius Lidali Wangula, a 40-year-old farmer. They live in Kapsoya, outside of Eldoret town. They have three children, aged 18, 11 and 7 years old, respectively.

Everlyne is a tailor. She has been in this business for the past three years with an income of 4,000 Kenyan shillings per month.

She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD., with which she plans to buy material to use in her shop. With the anticipated profits from the expanded business, she plans to grow the business and, in the future, buy a plot of land and build a house.

loans.use: To buy material to use in her shop

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en: Anecita S. is a 27-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a used-clothing business. She lives in Yulo Street, Brgy. 8, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her used-clothing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). Anecita is now borrowing PHP 28,000 so that she can continue to purchase more stock of used clothes to sell. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 26,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Anecita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending-team page on Kiva to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora is part of the communal bank “Esperanza de Colombo” and resides in the city of San Vicente. For the past four years, Aurora has been selling used clothing in a stand that she rents. It is located in the center of the city, beside her daughter's stand. Aurora attends to her business from Monday through Saturday from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m.
 
With this loan, Aurora plans to purchase merchandise and materials (paint and other items) to repair small damages to her stand caused by the February 27, 2010, earthquake. 

Aurora dreams of owning a car to manage with greater ease the purchase of her merchandise, as Aurora travels to Santiago every month, along with her daughter and her husband, who accompanies them when he’s off work. Aurora's motivation is to have sufficient economic security for her son; he’s 16 years old and has the capacity to continue his studies in the university.  

Aurora is pleased with how easy it is for Kiva partner Fondo Esperanza to provide her the funds of the loan, without many prerequisites. Aurora also values the entrepreneurial training delivered by her loan officer during the weekly meetings, especially the topic of how to administer your business. 

San Vicente de Tagua Tagua is a commune zone in the center of Chile, belonging to the Region of Libertador General Bernardo O’Higgins, located on the banks of the Estero Zamorano River. San Vincente de Tagua Tagua's main source of income is based on the production of lemons, oranges and avocados.

loans.use: Used clothes and repairs for her stand

loans.name: Christopher Kipruto

texts.en:
Christopher Kipruto M. is a 33-year-old man married to Irene M. and has two children aged two and eleven years. They live in Ngeria on the outskirts of Eldoret town. Christopher raises and sells livestock. He has been in this business for the past ten years, earning 15,000 KES per month.

Christopher was introduced to KADET by a credit officer. He is applying for his seventh loan of 90,000 KES from KADET, which he plans to use to purchase nine more head of cows to rear and sell later at a profit.

Christopher hopes to operate a large-scale livestock operation that would allow him to supply livestock to butcheries in Eldoret.

loans.use: To purchase nine more cows

loans.name: Annabel

texts.en:
Annabel L. is a married woman who lives in Sitio Toril, Bocana, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a small pharmacy and a Nipa business. Her husband Gilbert, who is 48 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 24 and 26 years old. 

Annabel joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Annabel has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, thus raising the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 26,000 which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she could continue to save up for her family's future and for improvements in their house. 

Annabel L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles K. is a 46 year-old man. He is married to Dinah K..  They have four children (26, 24, 20 and 18 years old). They live in Kuinet, an outcast of the town of Eldoret. Charles earns his income from farming.  He has been in this business for the past five years with an income of Kshs 4000 per month.

Charles was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer.  He is applying for his first loan of Kshs 20,000 with KADET LTD.  He plans to use this loan to purchase five bags of fertilizer.

Charles hopes to increase his farming business from a small scale to a large scale business and be able to take his maize to the cereals board.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida V. is 52 years old and married.  She supports her family by operating three business ventures: fishing, fish vending and candle vending.   She lives in Pandan, Brgy. Mahawak, Medellin, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her fishing, fish vending and candle vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7200. 

Leonida is now borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. 

Leonida aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Rode Maria

texts.es: Rode Maria a su edad de 32 años por eso creó un negocio como es una farmacia,  hace más de 3 años que este negocio le ayudó a responder a la necesidad de sacar adelante a su familia, ella atiende este negocio las 24 horas del día por lo que sus diferentes clientes llegan a su vivienda a buscar los medicamentos que ofrece. La mayoría de sus clientes también le realizan ciertas preguntas de medicamentos pues ella le brinda algunos consejos, pues también les ofrece medicamentos a un buen precio. Su mayor desafío es la innovación constante para sostener a su clientela. En la actualidad solicita su crédito para comprar una mayor variedad de productos farmacéuticos con el objetivo de diversificar mas la oferta.
texts.en: Rode Maria is 32 years old and she set up a pharmacy. She has had the business for more than 3 years and it has helped her meet her family's needs. Her store is open 24 hours a day for the various clients that come to her business in search of medicines that she sells. The majority of the clients also ask for advice on medications and she is able to guide them. She offers her prodcuts at a comfortable price. Her greatest challenge is offer innovation to retain her client base. She requests a loan to purchase a greater variety of pharmacy store products with the goal of improving her store.

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Sayyi Group

texts.en: Pictured here are members of the Sayyi Group. They run small scale businesses in Magburaka town, in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 800,000 leones each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. The leader of this group is William B.. William, age 52, was born in Mabonto village. He is married with eleven children. His wife is a businesswoman. Six of his children are attending primary school and five are in secondary schools. For many years now, William has been selling palm wine (wine tapped from palm trees), cigarettes, mints, biscuits, etc. William is requesting a loan of 800,000 leones in order to buy gallons of palm oil and cigarettes to add to his business.

loans.name: Heart Of Mary Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Corazón De Maria está conformado por Gary Antonio de 22 años de edad, es soltero y aun no tiene hijos El señor se dedica a la venta de ropa nueva, la cual distribuye principalmente de manera ambulante, pese a que también recibe pedidos para traer de Managua para vender en las diferentes zona. Cabe señalarse, el señor ya tiene 2 años de estarse dedicando a esta actividad, la cual surgió en principio con ayuda de su papa, el cual le prestó el dinero para comprar y vender ropa, y de allí fue que el continuo con el trabajo, ya al tener capital de trabajo. Algo que aduce el señor, es que en Nicaragua no hay trabajo, por ello es que uno se tiene que dedicar a algo honesto para ganarse la vida. Otra integrante del grupo es la Señora María Auxiliadora, la cual tiene 22 años de edad, es casada y tiene un hijo de 11 meses de edad.  Maria se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras de manera ambulante. Ella ya tiene 4 años de dedicarse a este negocio, el cual lo aprendió de su mama ya que ella la llevaba a vender frutas al mercado. Ella invertirá este crédito en la compra de frutas por cosechas para luego comercializarlas en los mercados.
texts.en: Gary Antonio is a member of the group named "Heart of Mary". He is 22 years old, single and he does not have any children. He sells new clothing that he distributes primarily by travelling door to door but he also receives orders in various regions of Managua. He has had 2 years in the business and he started out with his father's help.  His father loaned him some start up money to purchase clothing for resale. From there he started his business and he began to form a capital fund. Another member of the group is Maria Auxiliadora. She is 22 years old, she is married and she has an 11 month old baby. Maria sells fruits and vegetables by travelling door to door. She has had 4 years in the business. She learned the trade from her mother who used to bring fruits to sell in the market. She will invest her loan in teh purchase of fruit in wholesale to resell in the markets.

loans.use: Working capital.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more cartons of door locks, hinges, nails, zinc, hammers, etc. She describes herself as an honest woman whose goals are to improve her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Virginita

texts.en: Virginita A. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Tiling, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by fishing. Her husband Ronel, age 41, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business. They have five children who are 3 to 18 years old. Virginita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Virginita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 4,000 PHP, thus improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing 12,000 PHP which she intends to use for the maintenance of her fishing gear so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Virginita A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To fund operations

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maguinda

texts.en: Maguinda D. is a married woman who lives in Prk.II, Nangka, Brgy. Argawanon, San Remegio, Cebu. She earns her living with a handicraft business. Her husband, Max Arthur D., age 26, works as a construction worker to earn his living. They have four children who are 1 month to 6 years old. Maguinda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Maguinda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 14,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,000 PHP, thus improving the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing 19,000 PHP which she intends to use to purchase raw materials so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs. Maguinda D. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
