Mrs. Lim A. has planned to buy a vehicle many times but she never had sufficient money to buy one. Therefore, Mrs. Lim A. would like to take a loan to purchase a secondhand motorcycle for her transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Mirian Yolanda

texts.es: Mirian Yolanda P. Rodríguez es una joven de  28 años de edad, reside en la Comunidad de Palestina, Patuca, Olancho y se dedica a la venta de productos farmacéuticos. Mirian aprendió del negocio ya que laboraba en un consultorio médico y con el transcurso del tiempo fue obteniendo el conocimiento y la experiencia necesaria en el manejo de cada producto. Luego decidió que para tener un mejor ingreso económico ella debía establecer un negocio propio, así que fue comprando productos farmacéuticos en pequeñas cantidades y actualmente tiene una pequeña farmacia. Una de sus dificultades es que padece de presión y siempre está en tratamiento médico. Ella necesita el préstamo para incrementar su inventario y contratar a un empleado porque extenderá su radio de atención haciendo las ventas de casa en casa. Con el apoyo de este financiamiento espera aumentar sus ventas y a la vez obtener las ganancias suficientes para poder seguir pagando su tratamiento y su sostenimiento. Es su cuarto ciclo en FAMA y gracias a los préstamos que ha obtenido su negocio ha crecido y su nivel de vida ha mejorado.
texts.en:
Mirian Yolanda P. Rodríguez is a young 28 year-old woman who sells pharmaceutical products and lives in the community of Palestina, Patuca, Olancho.  Mirian learned the business from working in a medical office.  Over time, she gained the necessary knowledge and experience in how to use each product.  Then she decided that she should establish her own business in order to have a better income.  She bought pharmaceutical products in small quantities and now she has a small pharmacy.  One of the difficulties she faces is that she suffers from high blood pressure, so she is always under medical treatment.

She needs this loan to increase her inventory and to hire an employee, which will extend the area she is able to cover when making sales from house to house.  With the support of this financing, she hopes to increase her sales and to earn enough to keep paying for her treatment and to support herself.  This is her fourth loan cycle with FAMA and thanks to the prior loans she has received, her business has grown and her quality of life has improved.

loans.use: to buy pharmaceutical products

loans.name: Kunduzkan

texts.en:
Kunduzkan K. is a widow with four grown children. She lives in the southern city of Osh. 

Kunduzkan has a higher education and worked in the Osh State University for 22 years. In 1995, in order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, Kunduzkan started her business in trade.  She made wholesale purchases of women’s clothes and children’s footwear on the weekends, and then resold goods at the local market with the help of her sons. She worked hard and managed to open a small shop with different kinds of clothes. This activity allowed Kunduzkan to provide her children with a good education. 

Now  Kunduzkan is on pension but still is full of energy to work for the prosperous future of her family. This tireless insistence lead Kunduzkan to obtain two loans from Bai Tushum and Partners for business enlargements, which were repaid without any delays. Since this activity became a family business, Kunduzkan’s daughter-in-law helps her and works as a shop assistant. 

Now Kunduzkan wants to take a loan of 100,000 Kyrgyzstan Soms to broaden the assortment of goods in her shop. It will allow her to raise floating capital and increase her number of clients. Kunduzkan believes that her long-term experience and optimistic spirit will help her to improve her family’s lives.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase goods for reselling

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
This is Emma S., 48. She is a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Cancio S., a driver, and the mother of four children, one of whom is already working, while two are in high school. The youngest is currently enrolled in elementary school. By the grace of God, Emma has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college - a dream for most Filipino parents like Emma as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Emma maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct-selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange and others. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Emma dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes that she will be able to recruit many more women like her to her business. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship co-members* to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Phlek

texts.en:
Mrs. Phlek K. currently weaves cloth for sale. She sells her finished product to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes over 30 sets of cradles and mats before selling out. She also orders her products from her old and new clients and sells them to make additional income. 

Mrs. Phlek K. is married with two children who are attending public school, while her husband is working as a policeman. She would like to open a small business by selling a few grocery items, such as cooking ingredients, sweets and soft drinks, in front of her house. In order to start her new business, she needs more capital for buying inventory. So Mrs. Phlek K. is taking out her loan to purchase inventory for her new grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her grocery business

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen belongs to Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city and is known for its textile industry. She lives in a 2 room, brick house with her family in the area of Madina town. She moved there 3 years ago.
 
She is 37 years old, married to I. M. and has 4 children: 3 sons and a daughter. She couldn’t educate her children due to poor financial conditions.
  
She is a beauty expert and operates her beauty salon from home. Her husband has a job in a private firm on a monthly wage. Her cousin from her mother's side also lives with her family and contributes financially by doing a private job.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her beauty salon business. With the loan, she will purchase beauty products such as cosmetics, skin-creams and a hair dryer for her business. 
She hopes that this investment will bring positive changes to her business and that her monthly income will double.
 
She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She is confident there will be positive results from her business as a result of investment. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Perveen”.

loans.use: To buy beauty products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.en:
This is Wilfredo J., 52, a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Gemma Iskosa and is a father to a young, hard-working adult. By the grace of God, Willy has managed to support his child's schooling. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Willy operates a variety store while managing his junk shop. He is also landlord to a few transients who rent out a few rooms. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. He earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and reselling at piecemeal prices. Willy’s store, junk shop and rooms for rent are adjacent to his house. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.
 
To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting a Php20,000 loan. He will be using the loan to buy more products to expand his inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands.
  
Willy dreams of being able to renovate the family house soon with the proceeds of all his work in the business. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product range

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
This is Luzviminda R., 46, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Edwin R. and is mother to two young, hard-working adults and two school-aged children. By the grace of God, Luzviminda has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide for their everyday expenses.

Luzviminda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piecemeal rates.  Her store is adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Luzviminda dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, from the results of all her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Uranjargal

texts.en:
Mrs. Uranjargal is 44 years old and lives with her husband, Erdenesukh (48), and son, Munkherdene (16), in a rented house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has one more son who studies at a local University and lives separately. 

Uranjargal’s husband is a taxi driver. Since 1996 Uranjargal has been running a retail business. She rents space in Bayanzurkh market and sells a variety of domestic cleaning products. She buys her products from wholesalers who import them from China and Russia. Her starting capital was 500 USD. Today, her working capital is 2500 USD. 

She is a very hardworking and persistent person. Her future plan is to improve her family’s living conditions by buying a family house and to give her kids a good education. 

The loan Mrs.Uranjargal is requesting will be used to pay her son’s annual University fee and to increase her working capital.

loans.use: to pay her son’s annual University fee and to increase her working capital

loans.name: Marelin

texts.en:
This is Marelin S., 42, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Joel S. and is mother to their children. By the grace of God, Marelin has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide for their everyday expenses.

Marelin operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal, to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at piecemeal rates. Her store is adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands. 
 
Marelin dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with the proceeds from all her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory

loans.name: Rumaila's Group

texts.en:
Rumaila belongs to an industrial city of Pakistan called Faisalabad. She lives in a 2-room brick house in the area of Medina town. She moved here after her marriage with N. M. 23 years ago.

She is a housewife, prefers to stay at home and does her household work. She has given birth to 2 sons. Her eldest son is 22 years old and a tailor by profession and the younger one doesn't work.

Rumaila has applied for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. Her husband is involved in electronics sales business. He runs a shop in the market from where he deals with electronic items with his customers and generates income for the family. With the loan amount he will buy electronic items such as irons, televisions and ovens to sell through his shop.

Rumaila is hopeful that by using his experience of 20 years in this field, her husband will successfully be able to grow his business to a level where his family can have a better standard of living. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a good step for her family’s financial future. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Rumaila.

loans.use: To buy electronic items to resell.

loans.name: Fazeelat's Group

texts.en:
Fazeelat is the resident of Medina town which is a housing colony located in Faisalabad. Faisalabad is Pakistan’s third largest city and well known for its textile industry. She lives in a 2 room brick house with her family.

She has applied for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s electronic items selling business. With the loan amount he will buy electronic items such as irons, televisions and ovens to sell through his electronics shop and to make money for his family.

Fazeelat has given birth to 3 sons and a daughter. All of them are enrolled in a school and get their education except the youngest son who is just 3 years old. She herself is a school teacher and also sews clothes at her home. She knows the importance of education, which is why she wants her children to get the maximum education possible and improve their future.

She has good expectations from her husband that by using his 10 years of experience in his work, he will be able to gain maximum results from the investment. She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application with Asasah.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Fazeelat.

loans.use: To buy electronic items to resell.

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a 41-year-old married woman, mother of 5 children, living and working in Tyre. Khadija has worked in selling clothes from her house for 2 years because she believes that she has to help with her family's income and at the same time take care of her family members.

Khadija is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to do some important maintenance to her house before the winter season, finish the floor tiles, in addition to buying the new winter collection of clothes. Her clients are increasing slightly; her only obstacle was the cash problem that she faced. Khadija also sells scarves, because most of the people in her village use it. She hopes to increase her products more and more to add babies' and men's clothes.

loans.use: To buy the new winter collection of clothes to sell and to finish fixing her floor tiles.

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en: Sabah is a 29-year-old married woman who is the mother of four children. She has been the owner of a small mini market since 2000. She helps with her family's income while at the same time her husband works in agriculture. Her clients are loyA. because she serves them in a very polite way.  She hopes to expand her business into a bigger supermarket. Sabah is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy a car for her husband to help him transport his seeds and machines from one place to another.

loans.use: To buy a car for her husband's work

loans.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol C., 44, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Roy C. and is the mother of three young hard-working teens. By the grace of God, Marisol has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Marisol operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns income by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at the piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, Marisol is requesting a PHP 26,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Marisol dreams of being able to renovate her house soon using what she has earned with all her work in the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Robina Arif's Group

texts.en:
Robina is a resident of Siddiq Akbar town which is a housing colony located in Faisalabad. Faisalabad is Pakistan’s third largest city and is well known for its textile industry. Her home is a small one containing two rooms. She shifted here 17 years ago with her family. Robina is a housewife and the mother of three sons and two daughters. Her eldest son wasn't interested in education and started work as a painter a few years ago. Her other children are enrolled in school and are getting their education. 

Robina's husband has a business which sells construction supplies. He offers construction supplies to customers and earns money for his family. He has been doing this work for the past 15 years. Robina has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy construction supplies such as bricks, cement, sand, etc. to sell through his shop.  

Robina is hopeful that her husband’s business will improve through this investment in it. She is a new borrower from Asasah and hopes it will be a profitable experience for her family. 
Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Robina.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

loans.name: Nanci Yousaf's Group

texts.en:
Nanci lives in Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s third largest city and is famous for its textile industry. She lives in a two-room brick house with her family in the area named Medina town. She is a 49-year-old widow and lost her husband few years ago. It was a very difficult time for her and her family but she never lost hope. She raised her children with great care. Now both her sons sell sanitation supplies in the market and earn well from this business. Both of them respect their mother a lot and care for her the way she cares for them.  

Nanci is satisfied now that her sons are settled and operating their business. She has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her sons’ business. With the loan amount, her sons will buy sanitation supplies such as taps, water pipes, etc. to increase their sales. She is hopeful that her sons' business will improve and her family will have a better standard of living.
 
She wants her eldest son to marry and she hopes that she will be able to help him do it very soon with the help of profit from the loan. She is a new loan applicant and hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her family. 

Note: In the photo, Nanci is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy sanitation supplies to sell

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby C., 33, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Michael C. and mother to two elementary-aged children. By the grace of God, Ruby has managed to support her children's schooling. Now, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ruby operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns income by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at the piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business's operations, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Ruby dreams of being able to renovate her house soon with income from all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Abir

texts.en: Abir is a 40-year-old married man living with his wife in Chtoura. He has worked by transporting sand and rocks in his caterpillar (tractor) for the past 15 years. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to add to what he has saved towards the price of the new pick-up which he bought to increase and improve his work.  His clients are his neighbors and neighboring villages. His father’s support and his good reputation were the key to being introduced to his clients. He is working on expanding his work as much as he can.

loans.use: To pay for the new pick-up

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is a 39-year-old married lady who earns her living by operating a tailoring shop. She has four children. Her business, which is situated in Wayani, Malindi, has been in existence for the past five years and now she wants to expand it with the loan she has taken out. 

Elizabeth is taking out her second loan which amounts to Kshs. 30,000 from KADET LTD where she was introduced by another client. She wishes to expand her business by buying a modern sewing machine and materials for making clothes so she can satisfy the needs of her ever increasing number of clients. Elizabeth plans to use the anticipated profits from the business to help educate her children and help out with the family's needs.

She hopes to eventually grow her business and that one day she will own her own established boutique which would be able to serve her clients in Wayani and elsewhere.

loans.use: To expand the business by buying a modern sewing machine and materials

loans.name: Samina Nazakat Ali's Group

texts.en:
Samina lives in an industrial city in Pakistan named Faisalabad. She lives in a single room brick house in the area of Samanabad. She shifted here 15 years ago. She is 36 years old, married to N. A. and has five children. Only three of them could manage to get an education due to the family's poor financial situation. 

Samina is a working woman, doing embroidery and sewing work at her home. She receives orders from her neighboring clients and earns well by completing them on time. Her husband is a daily wage laborer. His income is not enough to meet the family's financial expenses. That is why Samina has to work fulltime to fulfill her family's basic needs.
  
She has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her embroidery business. With the loan amount, she will buy embroidery items such as beads, colored thread, clothes and sketches in bulk quantities that will help her to make more embroidered dresses and increase her income as well.  
She hopes that this investment will be profitable for her business and her family's living standards will improve. She is a new loan applicant and wants to build a long-term relationship with Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, Samina is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy embroidery items for her embroidery business

loans.name: Evelina

texts.en:
Evelina D., 57, is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Elpidio D., a taxi driver, and is the mother of a school-aged child. By the grace of God, Evelina has managed to support her child's schooling. Now, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Evelina as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Evelina oversees their tricycle operation and maintains a frozen food business. Customers order frozen cuts of meat like pork, poultry and beef. She also offers spiced native delicacies like sweetened pork, native sausages and other similar products. She pays cash to buy these items and adds a few pesos to the selling price to earn a profit, then sells them with payment due after one week's credit.
 
To help her continue operating her business, Evelina is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders of frozen cuts of meat for her customers and to buy materials to improve their tricycle unit. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Evelina dreams of being able to give her child a good high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy frozen meat for her customers' orders and other materials to improve her tricycle unit

loans.name: Tehmeena Muhammad Arshad's Group

texts.en:
Tehmeena is a resident of Samanabad which is a housing colony located in Faisalabad. Faisalabad is Pakistan’s third largest city and is well known for its textile industry. Her home is a small one containing two rooms. She shifted here after her marriage. She is 40 years old and has four sons and a daughter. All her children are getting an education except the eldest one who works in a hosiery firm. 

Tehmeena herself does sewing work. She receives orders from her neighboring customers and fulfills them on time and earns an income. Her husband has a printing press and offers printing services to his customers. He prints newspapers for his customers and generates income for the family. 

Tehmeena has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will buy printing toner and paper for his printing business. She is hopeful that this investment will be profitable for her husband’s business and increase his income. She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, Tehmeena is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy printing toner and paper

loans.name: Mousa

texts.en: Moussa is a 29 years old single man from Tyre He has been working at selling mobile phones and lines since January 2009. He also provides international and local calls with good prices per minute. A good number of foreigners, visit him and are steady weekly customers. His good reputation and the way he treats his customers are his supporting points.  Mousa is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy more mobile phones and accessories. Mousa has had no major obstacles since he started business. His friends are his clients and they support him all the time. Mousa is working on expanding his business as it is his main source of living.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phones and accessories

loans.name: Baby's Group

texts.en:
Baby lives in Faisalabad which is Pakistan’s 3rd largest city and famous for its textile industry. She is 40 years old and has 2 sons and 2 daughters. She is married to B. who is a private entrepreneur and has a fruit selling business. He has been doing this business for the past 12 years. 
Baby is a seam-stress. She sews clothes by taking orders in her areas. She is good at her art and receives regular orders. Her earning allows her to pay for the utilities expenses of her family. 
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan  her husband will buy seasonal fruits in bulk quantity for his fruit selling business.  Baby is hopeful that by investing the loan amount in her husband’s business, his business will be improved and his income will be increased. 

She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application. Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Baby”.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits in bulk quantity to resell

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin K. is a 38 year old single man who operates a food kiosk which has been in existence for the past 1 year. The business is situated in Sita, Malindi town where it serves Malindi town dwellers and passersby. 

Benjamin was introduced to KADET LTD by another client who is already a client of KADET LTD, and this is his second loan from KADET. The loan amounts is Kshs 30,000 and Benjamin plans to use it to add stock to his retail shop as well as repair the shop. Benjamin wishes to use the anticipated profit from the business to continue expanding the business so that he may later be able to own a well established retail shop and progress to own a supermarket.

loans.use: To add stock  to the retail  shop and make repairs to the shop

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
This is Mary Ann F., 45, resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Rodrigo F., a jeepney driver, and mother to four children. By the grace of God, Mary Ann has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send all of them all the way through college.

Mary Ann oversees operations of their jeepney** transportation business. They have both long (20-22 person capacity) and short (14-16 person capacity) jeepneys, all of which are meeting their daily capacity quota. Mary Ann’s husband also drives one of the jeepneys. 

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a Php30, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy eight new tires for the jeepneys. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Mary Ann dreams to be able to buy another jeepney soon. She also dreams that her children will finish their education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

**Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn income, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy eight new tires for the jeepneys

loans.name: Kishwer's Group

texts.en:
Kishwer lives in the third largest city of Pakistan called Faisalabad. It is also known for its textile industry. She lives with her family in the area of Samanabad which is a housing colony in Faisalabad.  She is 39 years old, married to A. G., and has 4 children: three sons and a daughter.  Three of them are getting their education from a local school.  

In order to financially support the family, Kishwer’s eldest son left his education after completing 12th standard and started working. He has a job in a medicine companyna d is on a monthly wage. 

Her husband has business of selling spices. He has been doing this business for the past 10 years and earns a good income. He not only sells spices through his shop but also supplies the spices to different grocery shops as well.   

Kishwer has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will buy spices such as red chilly powder, turmeric powder, salt etc in bulk quantity for increase his stock of spices for reselling. She is hopeful that her husband will be able to get positive results by investing this loan money into it. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application.  Note: “In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Kishwer”.

loans.use: To buy spices in bulk quantity for reselling

loans.name: Safari

texts.en:
Safari M. is a 33 year old married man and a father of two children. He operates a video show business which has been in existence for the past five years. The business is situated in Sita, Malindi town where it serves Malindi town dwellers and passersby. 

M. was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and he is applying for his second loan of Kshs.20,000 from  KADET. Mr. Safari is planning to use it to repair the business premises and add more sitting benches for his business. 

Safari wishes to use the anticipated profit from the business to continue looking after his young family, and to further expand his business. He would like to own a big video show whereby he would also be showing premier league matches form the Diaspora.

loans.use: To repair the business premises, and add sitting benches

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia K. is a 28 year old married lady with two children. She operates a tailoring shop in Sita, Malindi. She was introduced to KADET LTD by  one of the  clients of KADET. 

She is now applying for  her second loan of Kshs 30,000 and she plans to buy a modern sewing machine and materials for making clothes. Lydia hopes that, by doing this, her business will grow and she will be able to use the anticipated profit to help support her family as well as establishing  the business .In the future hopes to grow her business and own a boutique.

loans.use: To buy a modern sewing machine and materials for making clothes

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
This is Natividad F., 47, resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Fidel F., a groomer, and a mother to three young hard working adults, one of whom is still in college. By the grace of God, Natividad has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Natividad operates a variety store and a canteen. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling in piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 9, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Natividad dreams to be able to renovate her house soon, with some of the savings from her business. She also hopes to be able to continue supporting her youngest child who is still studying. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more supplies of groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
This is Concepcion L., 28, resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Joseph L., a security guard, and is the mother to two young children, one of whom is just starting his elementary years while the youngest is still toddling around at home. By the grace of God, Concepcion has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send both of her children all the way through college.

Concepcion operates a variety store where electronic cellular phone load has been incorporated into the inventory. She also does sideline work, doing direct selling of clothing, footwear and cosmetics. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling in piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php9, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy electronic cellular phone time from different network providers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Concepcion dreams to be able to encourage her family to join her faith, because as she said, “It is hard to achieve your dream if you are not active in your relationship with the Lord”. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene K. is a 29 year old married lady and a mother of three children. She sales water to residents of Kibokoni area in Malindi town where she resides. The lady was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing  client of KADET.  Irene has no history with  any other MFI,and she is applying for first loan of Kshs.16,000. 

Irene plans to use the money to expand her one year old business by buying a larger size water tank for her business so that she can be able to serve more clients. She intends to use the anticipated profit to help continue supporting her family as well as expand her business so that one day she may get to become a well established water vendor in the area.

loans.use: To buy a larger size water tank for business

loans.name: Connielyn

texts.en:
This is Connielyn M., 30, resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Danilo M., who is also her business partner. She is the mother to their three children, two of whom are already enrolled in elementary school while the youngest is still toddling around at home. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Connielyn, as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Connielyn operates a tailoring business. She mainly offers curtains, bed sheets, blankets, and other home trappings. Seasonal demands for clothing like uniforms and such are available all year round. She also does repairs and alterations. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.70 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Connielyn dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Sanobarhon's Group

texts.en:
Sanobarhon A. is the leader of the group. She is 39 years old and a widow. She has a son and two daughters, all of whom are in school.  Two years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 KGS, Sanobarhon started to sell convenience goods on the market. In this way she makes approximately $110 per month.  She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more goods to increase the turnover of her business and a refrigerator to store products. In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education.

Saerahon S. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 34 years old and married. Her husband works in Russia, so she takes care of two sons and a daughter by herself.  All the children are in school.  Saerahon is a farmer. She makes money by cultivating cotton and reselling livestock after fattening.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future she wants to provide her children with a good education and finish repairing her house.

Shohidahon T., 28, is married. She has a daughter and a son. Shohidahon is a school teacher and her husband works in Russia. She also makes money by reselling cattle after fattening.  In this way she makes about $65 per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a bull for breeding. 

Gulerahon T., 26, is married.  She has a daughter and a son.  Gulerahon breeds livestock for making money and her husband works in a factory.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase sheep for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase convenience goods

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion M. is from the village of East Poblacion, Sibutad. She is 57 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she operates a general store. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $30 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Consolacion joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Consolacion is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for the business. This will be her 3rd loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Aileen's Group

texts.en:
Aileen D. is from the village of Upper Disakan. She is 21 years old and the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Aileen is single and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Aileen works in someone else's business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoes in the local community. Aileen has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $66 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Aileen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand the product offering. 

Aileen is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Upper Disakan, Jose Dalman, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros M. is from the village of Marapong, Sibutad. She is 55 years old, married, and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she produces rice to sell. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-four years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Milagros joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Milagros is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for rice production. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for rice production

loans.name: Sammy

texts.en:
Sammy M. is 37 years old and married.  He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of the clients of KADET. Sammy operates a farming business, growing food crops which he later sells to customers in different areas in Lamu. The farm is situated in Hindi, Lamu where the gentleman stays.  This is his first loan of 25,000 KES from KADET LTD. He has never borrowed from any other micro-finance institution. 

Sammy intends to use his loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seedlings for his farm so as to continue farming. He wishes to use the anticipated profit to continue looking after his family and keep on growing his business. He hopes eventually to own a bigger farm as this will enable him to practice mixed farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and seedlings for his farm

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old married woman with one child. After her first child was born, she decided to help her husband with the household and  baby expenses, so she started working as a private teacher in her home. To receive the students, she has prepared a special education room.  

Today, she is requesting a loan of $500 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform modifications needed for the room. She needs to add more tables, a bigger wall and education tools in order to be able to receive more students with the coming school season.

loans.use: to perform modifications needed for the education room

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma A. is a 32-year-old married lady with three children. She owns a green grocery in Moi Veterinary, Malindi. The business has been operating for the past three years and now she wishes to expand it with the loan she is applying for from KADET LTD.

This is her first loan and she intends to add more stock of fruits and vegetables to enable her to serve her customers well. She also wants to repair the business premises so as to create growth of the business. She believes that then she will be able to satisfy her customers who are mostly the area  residents, and this will later improve her family's standard of living. 

Fatuma hopes to expand her business eventually so as to operate her own supermarket in the area.

loans.use: To expand the business by adding more stock of fruits and vegetables and by repairing the business premises

loans.name: Mamit

texts.en:
Mamit N. is a 46-year-old father of four children.  He lives with his family in Belovodskoe village, in the north of Kyrgyzstan.  He graduated from college and applied his knowledge to start his business in cattle breeding, which became the family's main source of income. 

With the initial capital of 10,000 KGS, he started this activity and achieved success. Today Mamit has one bull calf and five milk cows on his farm.  Gaining a wide experience in farming, Mamit also started to engage in cultivating grapes, which became his favorite hobby. Being a very purposeful and positive person, Mamit works hard to support his family.

Mamit plans to use this loan of 80,000 KGS to buy one milk cow and two bull calves for fattening and reselling. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing more cattle. As for the future, Mamit wants to buy a car for his family. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Erkinoi's Group

texts.en:
Erkinoi U. is the leader of the group.  She is 39 and married. She has two daughters and a son. All of them are at school.  Erkinoi is a farmer and her husband works as a truck driver.  Erkinoi cultivates cotton and also breeds cattle.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase a calf for breeding.  In the future she wants to repair her house and provide her children with a good education. 

Diloromhon M. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 41 and married. She has two sons and a daughter. The first son is a baker and the other children are at school.  Diloromhon works as a nurse in the hospital.  She also helps her husband to breed cattle. Selling six liters of milk every day, she makes about $43 per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a cow for breeding.  In the future she wants to purchase a piece of land and start building a house for her first son.

Tojimamat S., 37, is married. He has a son and two daughters, all of whom are in school.  Tojimamat breeds livestock and sells some animals every weekend. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase sheep in order to resell them at a higher price after fattening.
 
Mahmudjon U., 38, is married. He has two daughters and a son. All the children are in school.  Mahmudjon is a farmer who cultivates cotton for making money. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase cotton seed. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional electronic cellular phone loads for e-loading station and new mobile phone units and accessories to use

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married woman and the mother of two school-age children. A resident of Lebanon, she has owned a small grocery store since 1998. With her business income, she helps her husband to satisfy the heavy expenses of the family. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory and add new decor. She expects that her business will continue to grow in the coming year.

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships is an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: To increase her store’s inventory and add new decor

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mrs. Vann S., 45, married to local farmer So Kimhour, (shown in the photo) 48, always helps her husband in planting and farming rice.  Vann makes bamboo baskets for the market. To construct the baskets, she and her husband often go through the village looking for bamboo, take the material  home, submerge it in water for almost a week, and then allow it to dry under the sunshine for three days. They then tear the bamboo into smaller pieces and proceed to make the baskets. Vann is now requesting a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase more bamboo to resell to increase profit in her family.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo to resell to increase profit in her family.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros C. is 30 years old and his wife, Savin Phoek, is 26 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 2004 and have two young children, a son and a daughter. Ros is a television repairman. He works at his home. He does not have enough materials to operate the business, so he is requesting his first loan of $200 to purchase materials. Ros was not available for the picture, so his wife is pictured.

loans.use: To buy materials for his television repair business

loans.name: Bozo

texts.en:
Bozo K. is a 26-year-old man married to one wife. Together they have two children. Bozo owns and operates a retail shop in Mwangatini, Malindi town. The  customers of the business are mostly Malindi town dwellers and passersby. He has been in this business for six years.

Bozo was introduced to KADET Ltd. by an existing client of KADET Ltd. This is Bozo's first loan from KADET Ltd. and it is for KES 40000. He intends to use the loan to add stock to the shop and also renovate the premises and give it a face lift so as to boost the business. He wishes to use the anticipated profit coming from the business to continue looking after his young family and hopes that one day he may get to own a bigger, well established shop or even a supermarket.

loans.use: To add stock to the shop and renovate the business premises

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy materials needed for the production of polvoron, pastries and biscuits

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita P., 51, resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Norberto P. and is mother to three young hard-working adults. By the grace of God, Teresita has managed to support her children's schooling up to the college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Teresita operates a general merchandise store. Her store is basically a big convenience store, retailing in groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at a piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, beverages and others of the like to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Teresita dreams to be able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with this business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, beverages and others of the like to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Margaret  Njeri

texts.en:
Margaret is 40 years old and married to Charles T.. They have four children who are still financially dependent on them. She has been running the farm for a period of six years with a monthly profit of about KES 25,000. She is dairy farming and keeps poultry, at the same time.    

She wants to use the loan to expand on her poultry activity by purchasing more broiler chicks to raise and later sell, at a profit. She hopes to become one of the best poultry farmers in her location. She also hopes to see her children realizing their dreams in life.

loans.use: To expand on poultry activity by purchasing more broiler chicks to raise and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Perizat's Group

texts.en:
Perizat T. is the leader of the group. She is 35 and married. She has a son and three daughters. The son and two older daughters are at school, and the third daughter is still too young for school.  Five years ago, with the initial investment of 25000 soms, Perizat and her husband started to breed cattle. By reselling cattle after fattening, she makes 6000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. 

Svetlana B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37 and married. She has a son and a daughter, both at school. Svetlana and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding. They resell cattle after fattening. In this way they make 3000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Svetlana wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. 

Erkinbek S., 38, is married. He has two daughters and a son. The first daughter studies at university and the other children are at school. Erkinbek works as a private driver and his wife provides sewing services. They also breed cattle. With the money received from the loan, Erkinbek wants to purchase a bull-calf in order to increase the number of cattle. 

Kunduz A., 37, is married. She has a son and two daughters. Kunduz is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as a welder. Kunduz applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more cattle for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married man with 2 school-aged children. He lives in Lebanon. He has owned a car repair shop for the past 20 years. He repairs all type of cars and he has gained, over the years, a good number of clients. He works hard to meet his family's needs and to pay for his two children's schooling. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new mechanic's tools instead of the used ones that he has. This will help him to expand his business and he will be able to repair more cars to earn more profit for his family.

loans.use: To purchase new mechanic's tools.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mr. Pov P. and his wife, Mrs. Hoeun Veng, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1992 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of them attend school and the other one is still young. 

The family’s main source of income comes from his business building wooden houses. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. Mr. Pov P. does not have enough materials to operate the business. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase construction materials for his business.

Pov was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured.

loans.use: To buy materials for his wooden house construction business

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. Aun D. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Hin Khoem, live along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1983 and have eight children: three sons and five daughters. 

The couple has been growing rice for more than four years. In addition, they also grow cucumbers. Aun is a applying for a loan of $500 to continue her business by purchasing seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm and also to pay for plowing.

loans.use: purchasing seed, fertilizer and pesticide and also to pay for plowing

loans.name: At

texts.en:
Mr. At V. and his wife, Mrs. Yan Ken (pictured together), have been married since 1979 and have seven children--five sons and two daughters. Two of their children married and live outside the family home, two work in a garment factory, one is a fisherman and the other two are in school. The family lives approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mr. At V. and his wife are farmers. In addition to farming, he is also a fisherman. He is a applying for a loan of $1,000 to continue his business by purchasing seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his vegetable farm and pay for plowing fees.

loans.use: To use for farming

loans.name: James Muigai

texts.en:
James is 28 years old and married to Rosemary Wangeci, who is a housewife. He is a taxi driver and has been in the business for a period of six years now, with a monthly income of 17,300 KES. 

He wants to use the loan to start a retail shop for his wife. He plans to plough the anticipated profit back into the business for it to be stable. He hopes to help his wife create a stable, income-generating business. He also hopes to buy a car for taxi and other transport services in the future.

loans.use: To start a retail business for his wife

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap D. (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Cheng-ean Hean, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1984 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. Both sons are construction workers, one daughter is a garment factory worker, three attend school and the other one is still very young.

Sopheap has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a farmer and raises cows at home.

Sopheap has been working in the silk weaving business for long time, so she doesn’t want to change to another business. She has asked for a Kiva loan several times. She is now requesting another loan of $1,000 to continue her weaving business by purchasing silk materials. She will use part of the loan towards capital for her husband’s farming business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Sokleap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokleap C. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Sopheap Hay, have been married since 1993 and have three sons. Two of them are in school and another one is still very young. The family lives on an island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokleap has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old; weaving is a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished product to a middleman, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. 

She is asking for a loan of $200 to purchase silk material for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Chanhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanhorn S., and her husband, Mr. Lean Nau, live on an Island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2003 and have two young sons.

Chanhorn and her husband are weavers. They sell their finished products to the middle man in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. In addition to weaving, Mr. Lean was also hired by villagers to farm. He gets paid with fees, which he uses to support his family. Chanhorn has requested a Kiva loan before; she is now applying for another loan of $200 to purchase weaving materials for continuing her weaving business.

Chanhorn was not available for the picture, so her husband is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase cotton thread

loans.name: Aijan's Group

texts.en:
Aijan T. is the leader of this group. She is 42 and married. She has a son and three daughters. All the children are students.  Aijan works as a librarian at a school and her husband is a taxi-driver. Eight years ago, with the initial investment of 20,000 soms, Aijan started to sell convenience goods at the market.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to pay for her son’s education at university.  

Toktogul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 43 and married. She has two sons and two daughters. The first son works as a driver, the second is handicapped, and the daughters study at school. In order to make money, Toktogul sells fish and her husband works as a driver.  Selling the fish, Toktogul makes 15,000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more fish in order to increase the turnover of her business. 

Naryngul J., 57, is married.  Her husband is handicapped. She applied for the loan because she needs money to hire labor and start repairing her house. 

Satkyngul A., 42, is married. She has two sons and two daughters.  Her husband works as a welder. She applied for the loan in order to purchase building materials to start repairing her house. 

Sonunbubu A., 58, is married. Her husband works a private driver. Sonunbubu hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to pay for her grandson’s treatment (after a road accident). 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for her son's education at university

loans.name: Narin

texts.en:
Mrs. Narin S., 53, and her husband, Mr. Luch Tep (pictured together), 56, have been married since 1979 and have eight children--three sons and five daughters. The family lives along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Narin has been selling vegetables since 2000. Her husband gets hired by villagers to farm to earn money to support his family. 

The couple is in the process of building their new house to live in, and it isn’t finished yet. So, Narin is applying for her first loan of $500 to do the finishing touches.

loans.use: To finish her house building

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She established, 7 years ago, a tailoring business out of her home. She is specialized in sewing beads on the textiles.  As with the majority of Lebanese women, her story illustrates the day-to-day challenges in running a business to help their husbands with household expenses. Today, she is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase textiles and beads in order to expand her business operation to earn more profit.  This will be her second loan.

loans.use: purchase textiles and beads

loans.name: Jyldyz's Group

texts.en:
Jyldyz C. is the leader of this group.  She is 31 and married. She has three daughters; all of them are at school.  Jyldyz is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband takes orders to make iron gates.  Reselling cattle after fattening, Jyldyz makes 5000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more cattle to raise. In the future she plans to open a sewing workshop. 

Jyparkul K. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 31 and married. She has a daughter and a son. Her husband is a taxi-driver and she works in the Social Affairs Department.  Jyparkul and her husband also breed cattle to earn money. With money received from the loan, Jyparkul wants to purchase cattle to raise and hay to feed them during the winter season. 

Mirlan I. is 28. He works in the Police Department. Because of the low salary, two years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms, he started to raise cattle. He resells the cattle after fattening. In this way he makes 2000 soms per month. He hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to purchase cattle to raise.

Jyparkul U., 43, is married. She has three sons; all of them are at school. Jyparkul works as a baker and her husband is a mechanic.  Two years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Jyparkul and her husband started to raise cattle. With money received from the loan, they want to purchase hay for their cattle. In the future they plan to start repairing their house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a shop

loans.name: Alyiman's Group

texts.en:
Alyiman A. is the leader of this group. She is 59 and a widow.  She is a pensioner and receives 3000 soms per month.  Six years ago, with the initial investment of 25,000 soms, her son started to breed cattle.  Reselling cattle after fattening, he makes 8000 soms per month. Alyiman applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase two tons of coal for heating during the winter season. 

Nurgul C. is the treasurer of the group. She is 37 and married. She has a son and a daughter; both of them are at school.  Nurgul is engaged in cattle raising and her husband works as a private driver.  With money received from the loan, Nurgul wants to purchase coal for heating during the winter season. In the future she wants to purchase a vehicle.
